title: Mark Foster, from Foster The People: On Lollapalooza Chile 2025, his adventures in Santiago and writing an album about "what it is to be flawed as a human"
full_article: Foster The People's lead man shared his excitement over returning to Chile for Lollapalooza 2025. That‚Äôs kind of what we‚Äôre going for with this new live show. So it‚Äôs going to be a lot of energy on stage. You guys have the best fans. Which is what brings out the best in us.‚Äù  Wearing a white t-shirt, he‚Äôs all smiles as his Zoom camera displays a background that devoted fans will know best: his personal studio, the same that featured FTP¬†in the Live from my Den series¬†years ago. The Motel¬†sign has also stayed, with the lower section of its words almost unreadable ‚Äì yet recognizable, above his blond head. But time has, in fact, passed. A key element for whoever aspires to make a living out of songwriting. And yes, Foster The People might have been Foster & the People as first. But in a world where, sometimes, there‚Äôs little left to actual coincidences, the fact the band had to later readecuate its name because it was usually mispronnounced might not came out of the blue. The first shows they ever played were for charities. And even now,¬†Mark Foster cares about people. A lot. It‚Äôs been said parents don‚Äôt play favorites between their own children, but when it comes to artists and their pieces of work, things might turn out a little bit different. Because the 40-year-old creative has no hesitation in letting be known that, musically speaking, he reckons Paradise State of Mind as their¬† ‚Äúdeepest, most complex, rhythmic record ever made.‚Äù CNN Chile: It‚Äôs been such a long gap since Sacred Hearts Club, and even though this new album comes as a new era, it doesn‚Äôt lose the band‚Äôs spark. In the past, you‚Äôve described your favorite music to make as¬†intelligent pop and we actually keep that here.¬†Now one turns on the radio, hears a song and is able to go like, ‚ÄòYeah, this sounds like Foster The People.‚Äô How‚Äôs that done, as a producer? Building this indistintic brand and keeping it as an legacy?¬† Mark Foster: ‚ÄúOh, wow. Thank you. I think it‚Äôs really important for artists‚Ä¶ Uhm, I‚Äôll just say for me. It‚Äôs really important for me to grow in life and to take in new experiences and to really approach a record from a place of authenticity. And I try to express myself honestly with where I‚Äôm at and what I‚Äôve learned. Seven years is a long time. It‚Äôs a lot of light to let in and certainly for myself. Like, I‚Äôve changed. But then, also, the conversation with God. Which the funny thing about talking to something spiritual is that, a lot of times, you put it out there and you don‚Äôt hear anything back right away. CNN Chile: Since you brought up this spiritual matter ‚Äì these new songs feel like a psychedelic, lucid experience. Most of them are almost like seeing colors through your ears, if that makes any sense. MF:¬†I love that. CNN Chile:¬†And then there‚Äôs this deep vulnerability shown in the lyrics. The Holy Shangri-La, for example, comes to my mind, with the verse, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to know what is real, but all of my life I tried my best not to fear. The only way to get out is if we go through it all.‚Äù That‚Äôs pure hope, and written in such a beautiful way. How do you do that? How was creative process behind it? I studied the history of music and I‚Äôve listened to a lot of different types of music. But when I‚Äôm writing music, I tried to forget about all of that and I approach it like a four year old. So if I go over to the piano to start a song, I‚Äôll start hitting notes that may not work. I‚Äôm not worried about hitting the right notes. And the Divine, or whatever‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs an energy that will come in and just start kind of buzzing through me.  So it‚Äôs all from improve. And lyrics? Same way. So, once I get, like, a song going, I‚Äôll turn on a microphone and I‚Äôll just start singing. And a lot of times, words don‚Äôt come out right away. It‚Äôs just sounds. But then, a phrase will pop.
